column2: a YA romance about 17-year-old Sam Raines trying to find love in his maddeningly heterosexual hometown.  Sam has already dated the only other gay guy at his school
column3: his ex-lover turned best friend Landon. But now
column4: two years after breaking up with Landon
column5: Sam is ready to love again… but where could he find his perfect ten? He and his Wiccan friend Meg cast a spell on a list of what Sam considers to be the ten traits in a perfect boyfriend. And suddenly
column6: boys are popping out of the woodwork! There’s the suave new french exchange student
column9: all of whom seem suddenly drawn to Sam. Which one could be his perfect ten? You’ll just have to read it to find out!  Perfect Ten comes out June 6th
column10: so preorder today!  (P.S. enjoy this gem from our cover shoot!) " False text

column1: ebrpl 159692200873 "2017-04-17 22:00:40 GMT" https://ebrpl.tumblr.com/post/159692200873/hilary-mantels-ten-rules-for-writing-fiction "cheshirelibrary:  Are you serious about this? Then get an accountant. Read Becoming a Writer
column2: by Dorothea Brande. Then do what it says
column3: including the tasks you think  are impossible. You will particularly hate the advice to write first  thing in the morning
column4: but if you can manage it
column5: it might well be the  best thing you ever do for yourself. This book is about becoming a  writer from the inside out. Many later advice manuals derive from it.  You don’t ­really need any others
column6: though if you want to boost  your confidence
column7: “how to” books seldom do any harm. You can kick-start a  whole book with some little writing exercise. Write a book you’d like to read. If  you wouldn’t read it
column8: why would anybody else? Don’t write for a  perceived audience or market. It may well have vanished by the time your  book’s ready. If  you have a good story idea
column9: don’t assume it must form a prose  narrative. It may work better as a play
column10: a screenplay or a poem. Be  flexible. Be aware that anything that appears before “Chapter One” may be skipped. Don’t put your vital clue there. First paragraphs can often be struck out. Are you performing a haka
column11: or just shuffling your feet? Concentrate your narrative energy on  the point of change. This is especially important for  historical fiction. When your character is new to a place
column13: that’s the point to step back and fill in the details  of their world. People don’t notice their everyday surroundings and  daily routine
column14: so when writers describe them it can sound as if they’re  trying too hard to instruct the reader. Description must work for its place.  It can’t be simply ornamental. It ­usually works best if it has a human  element; it is more effective if it comes from an implied viewpoint
column15: rather than from the eye of God. If description is coloured by the  viewpoint of the character who is doing the noticing
column18: part of character definition and part of the action. If you get stuck
column19: get away from your  desk. Take a walk
column27: don’t just stick there  scowling at the problem. But don’t make telephone calls or go to a  party; if you do
column28: other people’s words will pour in where your lost  words should be. Open a gap for them
column29: create a space. Be patient. Be ready for anything. Each new story  has different demands and may throw up reasons to break these and all  other rules. Except number one: you can’t give your soul to literature  if you’re thinking about income tax." False link

ebrpl 158245751949 "2017-03-10 23:00:48 GMT" https://ebrpl.tumblr.com/post/158245751949/library-extension-for-google-chrome-makes-finding "cheshirelibrary:  We’ve just discovered something new – an extension for the Google Chrome  browser that allows you to find books
column2: music
column3: and more at your local  library as you browse the internet. That’s right
column4: you don’t even have to  be on our library website to see if we have a book you want! It’s  called Library Extension
column5: and it currently works only with the Google Chrome browser
column6: but will soon be available for Firefox
column7: as well.   This extension is kind of cool. Say you are looking up a book on Amazon (or Barnes and Noble
column9: Google Books) :   Library holdings show up right  on the screen
column10: letting you know if your local  library owns the book you are looking up. You can even place a hold on the library book  right from Amazon/GoodReads/etc!    Could be an easy way to save some money on books this year. Borrow before you buy!   Read more on The Cheshire Library Blog. " False link
